Author: (Middendorff, 1849)
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Glycymeris subobsoleta, an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: (Fabricius, 1780)
Critical Notes: Reported as Clinocardium ciliatum, an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: Whiteaves, 1880
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Macoma inflatula, an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: (Gould, 1850)
Critical Notes: Reported as Cyclocardia ventricosa, an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

In the field, mature Mytilus trossulus can often be distinguished from M. galloprovincialis, M. edulis, and related hybrids by examing the siphon-mantle features of the live animal. Identification by shell shapes and sizes is otherwise inconclusive and remains limited to the level of species complex.

Author: (Storer, 1838)
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Yoldia thraciaeformis, an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: (Valenciennes, 1846)
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Yoldia scissurata and Yoldia ensifera, unaccepted synonyms (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: (Gould, 1841)
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Yoldia hyperborea limatuloides, an unaccepted subspecies (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021); also reported as Yoldia amygdalea (Valenciennes, 1846), an unaccepted taxon (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021)

Author: (G. B. Sowerby II, 1842)
Critical Notes: The name Chlamys hastata hericia, reported by Dan Quayle (RBCM 989-00923-001), is unaccepted (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: (Hinds, 1845)
Critical Notes: RBCM records report this specimen under the name of Chlamys islandicaâan erroneous application of an Atlantic species concept.

Author: (S. S. Berry, 1953)
Critical Notes: McTaggart-Cowan reports Diplodonta orbella (=Zemysina orbella) (RBCM 979-00293). However, this taxon has since been split, with Zemysina orbella recognized as the southern and Zemysina impolita as the northern species.

Author: (Gould, 1850)
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Lyonsia californica (RBCM 979-03305). The original ID by Ian McTaggart-Cowan is Lyonsia pugetensis which is now accepted as Lyonsia bracteata (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: (Gould, 1853)
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Cylichnella culcitella, an unrecognized name (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: (Gould, 1846)
Critical Notes: Accessioned in RBCM collections under the name Cranopsis cucullata, an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: Williamson, 1905
Critical Notes: Reports of Crepidula cf adunca have been determined as Crepidula norrisiarum (Collin et al., in press).

Author: (Gould, 1847)
Critical Notes: Reported as Euspira lewisii, an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: (Carpenter, 1864)
Critical Notes: Reported as Vermetus compactus (Carpenter, 1864), an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: Kienberger, Carmona, Pola, Padula, Gosliner & Cervera, 2016
(MacFarland, 1966)
Critical Notes: Two subspecies are recognized: a Californian subspecies, Apata pricei pricei, as originally described from Monterey, California, and a Western Pacific subspecies, Apata pricei komandorica. No specimens have been sequenced to determine which subspecies are present in the Salish Sea. However, we do not appear to have the subspecies originally described in MacFarland 1966.

Author: Korshunova, Fletcher, Picton, Lundin, Kashio, N. Sanamyan, K. Sanamyan, Padula, SchrÃ¶dl & Martynov, 2020
Critical Notes: Currently, there is a sequence of Cadlina klasmalmbergi from Galiano Island in GenBank, but none of the other species that make up this complexâCadlina jannanicholsae, Cadlina sylviaearleae or Cadlina luteomarginataâare yet represented. Two of the three other species have been sequenced from BCâC. jannanicholsae and C. luteomarginata. The latter has been sequenced from Alaska and Washington and is therefore likely present in BC. Without more focused collecting and genetic study, however, one cannot be certain of the local diversity.

Author: MacFarland, 1966
Critical Notes: PMLS records list Cadlina luteomarginata complex due to challenges in field identification. However, here we recognize both Cadlina klasmalmbergi and Cadlina luteomarginata based on other confirmed observations. True Cadlina luteomarginata have more conspicuous tubercles and lack yellow glands near the mantle edge. Cadlina klasmalmbergi is more common in BC than C. luteomarginata.

Author: (M. Sars, 1829)
Critical Notes: Coryphella verrucosa was originally described from the Atlantic. Coryphella pseudoverrucosa has since been described in the Western Pacific, but a preliminary genetic comparison shows a difference between the Salish Sea specimens and those from the Western Pacific. Specimens have been collected from BC and WA but the paper confirming their identity has not been published.

Author: (Bergh, 1890)
Notes: Reported as Flabellina trophina; the photograph posted on iNaturalist does not appear to be what is now called Himatina trophina (kf)

Author: T. E. Thompson & G. H. Brown, 1984
Ekimova, Korshunova, Schepetov, Neretina, Sanamyan & Martynov, 2015
O'Donoghue, 1927
Notes: Reported as Acanthodoris pilosa (Abildgaard in MÃ¼ller, 1789)

Author: (Volodchenko, 1941)
Critical Notes: Specimens representing this species have not yet been sequenced, neither from the Salish Sea nor from the Western Pacific.

Author: Bergh, 1880
Critical Notes: Triopha modesta is recognized as a trans-Pacific species, and is most likely to occur off the coast of British Columbia. Triopha catalinae has been determined to be an Eastern Pacific species (but there is overlap). See Jung et al. (2020).

Author: Korshunova, Fletcher, Lundin, Picton & Martynov, 2018
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Zelentia pustulata, which is now recognized as being limited to the Atlantic. Our Pacific species is Zelentia nepunicea.

Author: (Bergh, 1904)
Critical Notes: There are three large tritoniids in the NEPâTritonia exsulans (formerly Tritonia diomedea or Tritonia tetraquetra), Tochuina gigantea (formerly Tochuina tetraquetra) and the true Tritonia tetraquetra, the latter of which, in the NEP, has so far only been found below 30 meters.

Author: (Middendorff, 1848)
Critical Notes: Reported as Cryptobranchia concentrica (Middendorff, 1848), an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: I. M. Cowan & G. M. Cowan, 1977

Critical Notes: "Tonicella undocaerulea is restricted to the Sea of Japan region (perhaps the Sea of Okhotsk as well). The species recognized as T. undocearulea in the Eastern Pacific is an undescribed species" (Roger Clark pers. comm. 2020).

Author: (Carpenter, 1864)
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Dentalium rectius, an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).

Author: (Whiteaves, 1887)
Critical Notes: Accessioned in collections at the RBCM as Cadulus hepburni, an unaccepted synonym (WoRMS Editorial Board 2021).
